results.title: The Art of hockey umpiring
results.brief_description: A detailed examination of the rules of men’s hockey including such pre match responsibilities of the umpire as personal equipment, dress, ground markings and the extent of the playing area under is jurisdiction. An investigation into common infringements of the rules as seen in context with the game. No other credits available.

results.title: The Art of French cooking
results.creator_credit: R&H Media Productions and Bob Bailey
results.brief_description: A film adaptation of Fernande Garvin’s best selling cookbook. Five famous recipes, using simple ingredients are demonstrated in easy to follow detail. Emphasizes the love and care lavished on ingredients in French cuisine. French toast sandwiches, French onion soup, fish fillets in sauce, beef bourguignon, and cherries jubilee are the featured dishes.

results.title: The Art of drowning
results.creator_credit: Film Victoria, Frame by Frame TV, Tony Wright and Jaems Grant
results.brief_description: Tommy and Ruth are two young friends living in a declining fishing community. Whilst Ruth loves the sea, Tommy would rather be pursuing his passions of painting, drawing and studying the lives of the great painters. His father, alarmed at the direction of his obsessions, exerts pressures on Tommy to join the family fishing business. During the holidays an old painter arrives to stay for the summer. His presence exerts a powerful influence on Tommy and changes the course of his life but not without a price.

results.title: The Art of conducting
results.brief_description: This unique program features sixteen of the greatest composers of the century in rehearsals and performance. This revealing and intimate archival footage is complemented by first hand recollections of the conductors in question, as well as with eminent musicians from today. Commentary is provided by the following artists: John Eliot Gardiner, Isaac Stern, Jack Brymer, Sir Thomas Beecham, Yehudi Menuhin, Oliver Knussen, Suvi Raj Grubb, George Szell, Bruno Walter, Otto Klemperer, Hugh Bean, Werner Tharichen, Richard Mohr, Leopold Stokowski, Julius Baker and Herbert von Karajan.

results.title: The Art of action: martial arts at the movies
results.creator_credit: Columbia Tristar Home Entertainment, Joni Levin and Keith Clarke
results.brief_description: Samuel L Jackson presents and narrates an exploration of the origins of the martial arts genre - the pioneers of the movement, change makers throughout the decades, and those who carry on the legacy today. Originating in China in the mid 1700s when Shaolin monks instructed Peking Opera performers, the martial arts genre has become synonymous with action and drama that would later be injected with romance, humour and visual wizardry. The program is structured in a question and answer format and focuses on key performers, characters, and directors: Wong Fei Hung, Jackie Chan, Jet Li, Tsui Hark, Ang Lee, Sammo Hung, John Woo and Michelle Yeoh to name a few. It also looks at the prominent role of women in the genre, the contribution of the Shaw Brother’s company in the 1950s, the influence of Japanese cinema (in particular the work of Akira Kurosawa), American cinema, and the direction of martial arts films in the 21st Century. Boasting an abundance of film clips and interviews with (unfortunately unnamed by visual clues) practitioners of the trade, this DVD provides an excellent history of the genre.

results.title: The Arsenal stadium mystery
results.creator_credit: G&S Films, Josef Somlo and Thorold Dickinson
results.brief_description: Scotland Yard investigates when a caddish footballer dies by poisoning during a game between Arsenal and the Trojans. This fast-moving British thriller provides authentic footage of the pre-war Arsenal team training, playing and relaxing: from goalkeeper George Swindin to legendary winger Cliff ‘Boy’ Bastin. Genuine footage of a 1939 Arsenal match is intercut with re-staged close-up action. Stars Leslie Banks, Greta Gynt and the players and management of Arsenal Football Club 1939. From an original story by Leonard Reginald Gribble.
